DEBATE ON BUDGET STATEMENT

(Business Motion)

     The Second Minister for Finance (Mr Lim Hng Kiang): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

   

     That, notwithstanding the Standing Orders, an additional day, namely, Wednesday, 10th March 2004, be allotted for the debate on the motion for approval of the financial policy of the Government for FY 2004/2005 moved by the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance on 27th February 2004.

 

 

    Many Members have indicated their desire to speak on the various issues raised in the Budget speech.  Some Members have been extremely diligent, proposing no less than 28 measures on the population issue.  So I think we need to extend the time to cater for all these proposals being put up.

 

    Resolved,

 

   That, notwithstanding the Standing Orders, an additional day, namely, Wednesday, 10th March 2004, be allotted for the debate on the motion for approval of the financial policy of the Government for FY 2004/2005 moved by the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance on 27th February 2004. - [Mr Lim Hng Kiang].

 

Column: 758

     ANNUAL BUDGET STATEMENT

 

     Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question [27th February, 2004],

 

      "That Parliament approves the financial policy of the Government for the financial year 1st April, 2004 to 31st March, 2005." - [Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance].

 

     Question again proposed.

     Dr Gan See Khem (Nominated Member): Mr Speaker, Sir, thank you for the opportunity to speak and to share my views on the Budget speech delivered so eloquently by the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance.

 

    Economists generally predicted that the world economy is in the midst of synchronised recovery and all the major emerging economies in Asia are likely to be buoyant through much of 2004.  The expectations are that China will remain the big industrial growth story, despite likely R&D revaluation.  India will continue to grow in the software and service areas.  Singapore and the rest of ASEAN will find growth niches.  Taiwan and Korea will emerge as investors.  It is heartening to note that we are looking towards a cyclical growth in the Singapore economy.  But when I read the Budget Statement by the Minister for Finance, I note that the Government is still concerned that the structural problems in the economy remain.

 

     I support the Government's pro-business stand in this year's Budget.  The business sector fully supports the Government's key pro-business initiative to cut the corporate tax rate by 2% to 20%.  However, it is disappointing to note that there is no corresponding cut in personal tax when the top rate stays at 22% and any further reductions are mothballed till an economic recovery is more certain.  The maintenance of the

Column: 759

personal income tax regime signifies that there is not going to be an attempt to encourage spending and consumption, except for the cut in the price of car ownership.  And as every entrepreneur will remind us, business prospects are important or may be even more important than tax cuts.

 

     The Budget does reflect positive changes for entrepreneurs, especially with the $100,000 exemption of chargeable income for a new company which applies to each of the three years falling within the Year of Assessment 2005 to 2009.  The Budget proposal to exempt foreign source income for individuals is a good move to attract the large pool of resources currently residing out of Singapore to be remitted back home.  This will have an enhancement effect on the local wealth management industry.  Whilst these are encouraging moves by the Government to boost the local business activity, the question that needs to be addressed is whether the above pro-business changes are enough to create a vibrant business climate in Singapore and attract not only creative local but also foreign entrepreneurs to set up business here.

    

      Please allow me to identify a few areas where further enhancement may be needed.

 

     First, on corporate tax.  The question I would like to ask the Government is whether the 20% tax cut is the end of the road.  Is this the target the Government has set itself to achieve or the limit that it would accept?  Would the Government consider a further cut to 17.5% corporate tax rate to be competitive with Hong Kong, or even to consider the 12.5% level to be in line with the corporate tax rate in Ireland?  Hong Kong companies have the advantage of being the gateway to the enormous Chinese market.  Despite its economic woes over the last few years, Hong Kong-based companies are now

Column: 760

riding the wave of the spill-off of the economic expansion in China, and they also enjoy a favourable and simple tax regime. 

 

     Personal income tax is at 15.5%, though it will be increased to 16% in the coming financial year.  In Hong Kong's case, there is no capital gains tax nor is there a tax on dividends or interests.  Hong Kong has no sales or value added tax.  In Ireland's case, the pro-business regime has brought enormous economic benefits of attracting new and creative entrepreneurial activity than any other countries to-date.  Singapore's effective corporate tax collection is lower than the 20% that we announced, due to the tax holidays and pioneer status given to MNCs. 

    

      In the early days of our economic development and our attempt to attract more MNCs to Singapore, the provision of pioneer status and tax incentives was a very important key tool to attract these enterprises to Singapore.  But as we move towards a regime whereby we want to promote entrepreneurialism and we want to have a more entrepreneurial economy, then it is time that we reviewed the pioneer status and the tax incentives accorded only to MNCs.   This system penalises other companies because we are all supporting pioneer companies.  In order to create a more entrepreneurial Singapore, we need to have a simple and transparent low-tax regime that uniformly applies to all companies and not only to pioneer status given to selective MNCs.  I believe a simple and a low-tax regime would do its part to encourage not only MNCs but also other entrepreneurs and SMEs to set up their base in Singapore.

    

      The pro-entrepreneur initiative articulated by the Finance Minister is a welcome change and is a good intention on the part of the Government.  The question most of the start-up entrepreneurs that I have spoken to asked me is

Column: 761

whether that is enough, or that is relevant.  As most of us know, very few enterprises make money in the first three years and, if they do, there is no reason why we need to cap their tax incentives at $100,000.  In fact, many entrepreneurs out there have asked whether the Government will review the three-year limit and, say, extend the tax holiday to seven years to make these tax incentives more meaningful to new enterprises.  The business sector really applauds the Government's move to cover all set-ups under the Enterprise Investment Scheme which really gives opportunities to other budding entrepreneurs like BreadTalk.

    

      Before questioning if this is enough, can we also look at the Irish example because, in addition to the tax incentives, Ireland has put together many grants and other schemes to help start-ups and new enterprises?  An important part of the Irish incentive package is the availability of grants towards initial start-up costs.  Cash grants are given towards the cost of fixed assets, and these are available to companies to help defray the cost of setting up the operations.  Fixed assets are eligible for assistance, including site purchase and development, buildings, new plants and equipment.  Of special interest is the employment grant which is specifically geared towards companies which create employment but do not need to invest heavily on fixed assets.  These grants are non-taxable.  An amount will be approved for each job created.  Ireland has given generous grants and made these available towards the cost of major training initiatives by companies, so that companies can substantially upgrade their skills base.  What they also have is that grants are available for the development and expansion of an R&D facility.  The cost available for the grant includes expenses for the acquisition of sites, premises, plant and equipment, wages

Column: 762

and salaries, materials, services, consultancy fees, feasibility studies and technology acquisition.

    

      Would the Government consider giving tax deductions for investments and not failure as an incentive for a less risk-averse investment climate?  For example, in the United Kingdom, individuals get tax exemptions upfront, even if companies fail.  If Singapore were to have enough angel investors to fund new and exciting business enterprises, could we allow angel investors to claim for tax losses for the full amount of investment losses?  A more supporting tax regime will be required to create a more vibrant new business investment climate in an entrepreneurial Singapore.  With these tax changes, we can hope to attract high net worth individuals to reside and invest in Singapore.

    

      The creation of a vibrant and enterprising Singapore will require mindset changes as well as physical policy changes.  We need to highlight a more consumption model in our economic planning and encourage more private sector initiative into how we manage our enormous national savings which are now channelled primarily through overseas investments through GIC and Temasek and other Government-linked companies.  There also needs to be more institutional shift to encourage entrepreneurialism.  We note that the Finance Minister has proposed a deficit budget this year, and the business sector hopes that he will continue to promote a deficit budget for years to come.

    

      Our Constitution promotes prudence

and conservatism in our fiscal policy.  This is really very useful for Singapore in the years where we have double-digit growth.  When the economy slows down and when the economy is mature, we do not see an era where we have double-digit growth again.  I would like to request that the Government review and re-appraise

Column: 763

the Constitution which forces such extreme fiscal conservatism and promote a period of internal generated growth.

 

     I hope we are not the generation which is accused of selling the family jewels, as I talked about encouraging more aggressive fiscal policies.  But in an era where there is intense competition for talent, new enterprises and innovation, I think the need for a change in institutional mindset needs to prevail.

     Dr Wang Kai Yuen (Bukit Timah): Mr Speaker, Sir, the economy is recovering.  All indicators point upwards.  Companies are starting to hire again.  Confidence of the people is slowly recovering.  Consumption is picking up in all sectors: housing purchases up, home improvements up, travel up.  Everything is up.  Everyone breathes a sigh of relief.  There is a feeling in the air that good time is just around the corner.  While the common man might have short memory, the Government should retain the institutional memory of the lessons learned in this most severe recession we have just endured.  In this respect, the Government's decision to cut the budget by 2% per year for two consecutive years is noteworthy.

 

     Mr Speaker, Sir, following its usual practice, the Feedback Unit conducted three pre-Budget Statement dialogue sessions.  In these sessions, the participants did not provide any new ideas or suggestions.  Generally, the sentiment was for the Government to hold the ship steady.  Keep the cost of doing business down.  Reduce land cost.  And, as usual, the plight of the SMEs in obtaining finance is also raised.

 

     On the personal tax arena, most contributors emphasised that the middle class needs some relief as the lower income groups have been the focus of Government largesse in the past. 

Column: 764

Generally, while people harboured some wishes on the Budget Statement, they were not expecting too much.  They knew that the tax revenue is down and the Government's budget is in deficit.

 

     A refreshing suggestion was made by an accountant to do a total review of our tax regime system-wide as the current one was based on an entrepot economy of Singapore in the early 1900s.  Our economy today is much more diverse and complex.  We are trying to develop a vibrant wealth management industry.  Doing so would require a different tax regime.  Exempting an individual's foreign sourced income is necessary in this context.  I am glad that the Minister has finally accepted this recommendation after this proposal has been repeatedly raised in a wish-list in feedback sessions.

 

     Mr Speaker, Sir, the Minister has reduced corporate income tax from 22% to 20%.  Tax reduction is always welcome.  However, this would primarily benefit existing companies that are profitable.  It still leaves the rest of the companies which are trying to break-even in the cold.  These companies would have benefited more from lower costs of doing business, such as statutory levies, taxes and fees.  With the expiration of some of the tax rebates, in fact, for these companies, costs have gone up again.  Thus, it is regrettable that the Minister did not continue some of the cost reduction measures like property tax rebates.  It would have been more welcome if the Government could have brought about a permanent reduction of these costs, instead of just providing a temporary relief.

 

     Sir, the Feedback Group on Finance and Small and Medium Enterprises has called for measures to help SMEs to increase their access to financing.  I am glad that the Minister has finally agreed to a measure through securitisation.  We

Column: 765

look forward to greater details on how SMEs could operate under the new scheme.

 

      I am also heartened that the Minister addressed the middle-class squeeze by reducing the ARF from 130% to 110%.  This is indeed a much welcome move.

 

     Mr Speaker, Sir, in addressing the future of Singapore, although he did hold out a vision of Singapore as a Land of Opportunity, the Minister's primary focus on the future is on the declining birth rate of Singaporeans.  He informed the House that measures to encourage more women to have babies would be implemented once the inter-ministerial committee headed by Mr Lim Hng Kiang has finished its work before National Day.  Many speakers before me have touched upon what these measures could be and I would not dwell into them, except to say that we should not stop there.  We should look into the future, into what Mr David Lim called the "emotional aspect" and what Mr Ang Mong Seng called the "family value".

 

     Sir, I believe that the number of children a couple would have is largely determined by the value the couple placed on family.  If they grew up wanting a larger family, they will have a larger family despite all the financial burden.  If they grew up placing greater importance on creature comfort than children, they would have one, two or, sometimes, zero children.  Thus, to redress the declining birth rate, we must inculcate the correct values of on our people from young.  There are really no quick fixes.

 

      The intrinsic burden of having children is well illustrated in the "Cashflow" game designed by Robert Kiyosaki of "Rich Dad, Poor Dad" fame.  It is a board game much like Monopoly with the roll of a dice to determine the number of steps one's chip

Column: 766

moves on the board when your turn comes up.  The game is designed with the objective to teach players money management concepts to enable them to get out of the so-called rat race.  As a wage earner, one gets out of the rat race when one's unearned income exceeds one's monthly expenditure.  Sir, my wife was very much taken up by the educational value of the game and got everyone in the family to play the game.  In this game, the player learns to invest in rental properties, stocks and shares so that the unearned income will go up.  Sir, the spoiler in the game in getting out of the rat race is the cost of bringing up children.  Whenever one has the misfortune to draw a card indicating that a new baby was born in the family, the chance of getting out of the rat race gets very much worse.  When the number of children exceeds three, there is practically no chance of getting out of the rat race no matter how high is your income.   After a few games, even my 9-year old son would groan whenever he draws a baby card and say, "No, not again, another baby."  Sir, this is what we got when we did not pay attention to the inculcation of family value in our youth and focused on the material incentives in motivating our people in the past.

 

     Sir, in real life, whether we are conscious of trying to get out of the rat race or not, we intuitively link the cost of bringing up children with our personal financial well-being.  From a dollar and cent point of view, in modern day concept, it is true.  This being the case, I urge the Committee led by Mr Lim Hng Kiang to consider how we can address the value system of Singaporeans - how to inculcate the love of a bigger family in our young people.  Of course, Sir, this would take at least a decade to show effect.  As a society, we must take a total approach to this problem.  True, by all means, introduce measures, financial incentives needed to turn the situation around but we should not forget the long-

Column: 767

term measures as well.  For instance, we might get MOE to include a pro-family concepts in our moral education and National Education curriculum.

 

     Sir, the Minister also commented that the economic uncertainty since 1998 also contributed to the plunge in the total fertility rate.  The experience of many of our unemployed in the age group of 50s now with teenage children still in school would surely put a damper on our younger people in having children.  To turn around the declining TFR, we must instill confidence in our people about the future of Singapore.

 

     While it is true, Sir, that our economy is recovering, I suspect this recovery in the manufacturing sector, at least, feels like a rebound and not a solid recovery based on concrete fundamentals.  The rebound of business activities is probably due to an increase of the utilisation of the existing capacity in our plants and equipment.  I see that, concurrently, the hollowing out of our manufacturing would continue unabated as China continues to impress with its manufacturing prowess.  In the IT sector, India is the rising star.  Have we downsized sufficiently to once again be attractive for foreign investors?  The marketplace would tell us soon enough.

 

     Sir, I believe that this recovery is giving us a breathing space, a temporary relief from the unrelenting global realignment of production capacity for best return on investment.  It is paramount for us to make use of this breathing space to transform Singapore.  To me, Sir, just cutting costs alone, be it in Government or in private sector, is not the way forward.  The logical conclusion of just cost cutting while leaving everything unchanged is to bring us down to the same standard of living as our lower cost competitors.  This is not something even the most ardent cost-

Column: 768

cutters, like Mr Inderjit Singh, would want.

 

     Mr Speaker, Sir, I find it invigorating that the Minister has held out the goal of transforming Singapore into a Land of Opportunity.  This is an exciting vision.  I hope he will find another occasion to flesh out this vision.  Furthermore, this vision energises every segment of the society, rich, poor, young or old.  It must be a Land of Opportunity for every Singaporean.  It should not be a Land of Opportunity just for the talented or the rich.

 

     Sir, what would constitute a Land of Opportunity?  Whatever the definition, I find it difficult to acclaim that ours is a Land of Opportunity if our economy were to grow at an anaemic 2-3%, the long-term sustainable level of a mature economy.  I would interpret the Land of Opportunity to mean that we must transform our society so that our economy would be humming along nicely at a 7% or 8% annual clip.

 

     Sir, at the moment, it seems to me that our economy has lost its forward momentum.  Like a car with one of its wheels spinning

in a slippery pothole, it would be hard for the car to move forward on its own steam without an external push.  Today, we have a first-world standard of living, a first-world cost of doing business without the depth and width of the knowledge and technology that underpin the strength of a first-world economy.  As our competitors adopt our economic strategies, we found ourselves behind the 8th Ball.

 

     Sir, it is not always so.  In fact, Singapore has become a model of other resource-constrained societies.  In the March 2004 issue of National Geographic that features on Armenia, Singapore was repeatedly held up by the Armenians as a model for the landlocked country to develop a viable and dynamic economy.

 

Column: 769

     As others look towards us for inspiration, where do we look in turn?  What is the model for us?

 

     Sir, we have tried to emulate the industrialised countries to develop our own intellectual properties in R&D.  Despite all the money NSTB has disbursed to IT R&D, we have been less than successful in that area.  Today, the focus of A*STAR is on life sciences.  What were the problems that we had run into?  In short, problems of a small population size, lacking economy of scale because of the miniscule domestic market.  I suspect we would continue to have minimal success if we were to emulate the paths taken by economies much larger than ours.  Our population base is just too small.

 

     Sir, how do we become a Land of Opportunity?  I do not have the answers, but I believe we need to think out of the box in several areas.

 

     Firstly, we need to review whether Singapore is destined forever to have a very small population.  The last Government planning target I recall reading in the newspapers was five million.  If that were the case, we cannot even compete or compare with a city like Hong Kong or Taipei, not to mention Shanghai or Beijing.  All of us grew up with this mindset that Singapore is a small country.  We have limited land.  We do not have sufficient water.  To achieve a measure of self-sufficiency, we set aside close to one-third of our prime land for water catchment.  Because of these constraints, yes, we will always have a small population. 

 

     There are many limitations with a small population, least of which is our mindset.  I will give one example.  For instance, because we believe that we cannot produce sports champions from

Column: 770

such a small population base, we do not even try.  What is the problem with this mentality?  This mentality seeps through the population and, today, we have young Singaporeans who would not even try when they perceive that they are faced with insurmountable hurdles in whatever they pursue.  I was shocked when a HR manager told me that when it sought interns among the students in a MBA programme in Singapore, all the applicants were PRC or Indian students.  No Singaporean students even attempted, because they have already concluded that they would not be good enough.  Maybe we did a very good job of convincing ourselves of the superiority of foreign talent.  But not even try?  That is the depth of our lack of self-assurance, our lack of self-confidence.  Clearly, Sir, this is a mindset we must get rid of.

 

     Sir, so long we depend on rainwater and water from Malaysia to supply our drinking water, there is indeed a limit to the population we could support on the small land area of our island.  Thanks to former Prime Minister Mahathir, we were forced to take the dramatic decision to recycle our sewage water as NEWater.  When Prime Minister Goh took a swig of the NEWater and the population followed at many National Day dinners, I believe we had broken this mental constraint on our own potential.  Now that we are prepared to accept NEWater, we are indeed liberated from the stranglehold of limited water supply.  This being the case, Sir, we could support a much larger population in Singapore.  In my mind, we could probably double our population to eight million.  If we could accept this as a planning premise, we would be talking about a very different Singapore.

 

     Secondly, we could have exploited our strength as a safe and peaceful oasis in a world of turbulence.  Our competitors in the economic arena would not be able to replicate this in their countries.  We could leverage on this reputation to develop into

Column: 771

a fun city where high net worth individuals could come to have fun and recreation.  Here, we are only limited by our own imagination.  Looking at others, I am particularly impressed by the United Arab Emirates, where they have recently developed two fern-shaped islands.  Sir, this is an impressive leap of imagination for a desert people.  On these islands, most of the waterfront properties are taken up by wealthy westerners whose lifestyles are very different from the Arabian culture and religion.  Yet, the people of UAE are able to accept having areas in their country where an international lifestyle could be maintained without the rest of the country having to give up its traditional values.  Could we have done the same?  In our recent sales of Sentosa Cove, could we have emulated UAE and opened the sales to an international clientele resulting in a very, very different Sentosa Cove?  Could we have changed our mindset to transform Sentosa island into a resort for the rich and the famous?

 

     Mr Speaker, Sir, these are just two possible scenarios.  I am sure if we put our best minds together, many more great ideas challenging our conventional wisdom will surface.  Some of these will be really exciting.

help parents cope. For us to succeed, we will need to overweigh family values and underweigh materialism.  In fact, I would go so far as to say that underlying all these is, in fact, a shift in the value system over the last 30 years or so.

 

     I remember that in the not so distant past, we had less to eat and wear, but we had more children to show.  Children were a sort of status symbol and, hence, the more the merrier. Today, it is the reverse.   Having a child is seen as a cost that even the well-to-do are unwilling to afford. Hence, while in the past having children is an automatic next step, today, we analyse and analyse the cost until we become paralysed by it. It is now an option and not a value proposition.

 

     The value transmission chain is broken, I suspect, when the extended families in kampongs were broken.  In almost all families then, the generation of elders are the natural advocates of pro-family and procreation values.  Their pleasure and joy at the announcement of a new marriage or the arrival of a new baby in the extended family are great encouragement for young couples to procreate.  The extended family is a natural walking advertisement and reminder transmitting pro-family values.  This is evident during Chinese New Year, where the pressure would be on singles and childless couples, myself included. Today, there are tours and escapades to help ease this pressure.  We need to reconnect this value transmission chain - not so that I myself will be under pressure, but to solve the real issues of caring for the young.  Many modern grannies these days also want to have fun.  We need policies that will encourage the re-formation of extended families.

 

     I would like to give a couple of suggestions here where HDB is concerned.  It is quite a unique situation in Singapore where marriage and

Column: 792

procreation are sometimes tied to housing policies.  While there are incentive schemes to encourage newly-weds to live near their parents, this scheme suffers from two inherent deficiencies.  First, many newly weds prefer new flats which are directly purchased from HDB at market subsidised rates.  Currently, the CPF housing grant of $30,000 to encourage young couples to live near their parents is applicable only to first-time applicants and applies only to HDB resale flats.  Our matured parents already living in HDB flats cannot sell their flats and apply for the grant to live near their young married child.

 

     Second, the advantage of proximity is not heightened until the arrival of the first child.  By then, either the the flats in mature estates are not available or the young couple has yet to fulfil the 5-year occupancy rule.  I have received many requests for help by my Punggol 21 residents, and Sengkang residents as well, who are unable to obtain 4-room flats for their parents as these flats have been exhausted and what remain are bound by the ethnic quota.  In other words, they are in a Catch-22 situation.  I hope the relevant Ministry can do something about this.

 

     The erosion of pro-family values is evident in the rising rate of divorce.  At the centre of this debate is our social aspiration for the 5 "Cs", meaning credit card, career, car, condominium and certificates.  We have problems as long as child bearing ranks after these 5Cs.

 

     Ideas about children and the role of each spouse should also be discussed prior to marriage.  Too many couples leave these issues to be negotiated until after marriage. The fact that married couples are off our radar screens until they turn up at the doorsteps of our courts means that the family care programmes available today may be too late and too little for many couples.

Column: 793

 

     In fact, a Research Bulletin from our Subordinate Courts suggested that the birth of the first child was a major transition that caused disruption and conflict between parents.  Too many families were not coming through this transition intact.  I urge the MCDS to work with various agencies to identify couples at risk before they land up in courts.  A good opportunity is to get parents waiting in the queue at polyclinics for their babies who are getting their innoculation to simply fill up a survey form to describe the state of their marriage, stress level and whether the mother suffers from post-natal blues.  The information gleaned from such surveys can help to identify couples at risk and channel them for counselling before they break up.

  

     Again, as I have said, there have been quite a number of suggestions given by Members of this House on measures to help mothers and, in fact, fathers to cope with the weight of procreation.  So, I will not dwell on them except to emphasise that all these measures and facilities, like infant care and childcare, should form a part of an unbroken continuum of family care and social support infrastructure.

 

     Next, I would like to move quickly to the cost factor.  The cost factor has been mentioned many times, both by my residents whom I have spoken with, as well as by Members of this House.  My sense is that the cost factor, real as it may be, is only as important in relation to the social value that they have.  Having said that, I would still like to see the Government helping not just to subsidise the cost per se but to lower the cost of having babies, and also extend some of the current tax incentives.

   

     First, the baby bonus under section 42A of our Income Tax Act which applies only to the second and third child.  My question is:  why such a restriction?  This

Column: 794

means that in the case of twins or triplets, the mother would be deemed to have automatically exhausted her entitlement and, by some stroke of miracle, no longer require any more maternity leave or cost subsidy should she be pregnant again.

  

     Another is the tax rebate for graduate mothers which applies to graduates up

to 28 years old.   Data from the Department of Statistics showed that graduate women are, on average, marrying at 27 to 28 years of age.   This means that half of our graduate women will not be eligible for the tax rebate at all! And more if they do not conceive immediately after marriage.   I urge the Government to urgently review this age criterion.

 

     We must also address the cost equation of declining fertility due to late marriages and genuine infertility. After all, it was cited that Singaporeans have one of the lowest sperm counts in Asia. During my MPS, I saw a young couple who were graduate professionals with stressful work environment. They love children but could not conceive.   They were only 32 years old, and were turning to IVF.   The success rate of IVF, I understand, is low and the cost is about $9,000 per treatment.  They would like to have three children and, by simple calculation, it would cost them about $81,000.  At present, only a maximum total of $4,000 per treatment and a lifetime ceiling of $12,000 may be withdrawn by a woman from her Medisave account to pay for IVF treatments.   Given that more couples may be turning to IVF, I urge the Government to review the maximum withdrawal allowed from Medisave for IVF treatment.  Do not penalise them; help them.

 

     Next, I would like to move on to the aging society.  While we speak a lot in this House about the slew of pro-family and pro-marriage proposals, we must not also forget the singles who have

Column: 795

contributed to Singapore and are most vulnerable in their golden years.  Recently, a 52-year-old single lady, Miss Tay Huang Huang, came to me for help.   She works three-quarters of the day and hurries home to look after three elderly siblings who are also single and suffering from stroke and mental handicap.  The 52-year-old herself suffers from depression due to her stressful home environment.   She has not been able to find a home that will accept all four of them.   She is worried that, with age and a deteriorating health, she may not be able to look after her siblings.   In fact, she may not be able to look after herself!   With advancement in medical science , which is also expensive, she is also afraid that she will outlast her resources.   She is feeling both desperate and helpless.

     Mr Speaker: Miss Low, you have two minutes left to wind up your speech.

     Miss Penny Low: I recount her story here to highlight the fact that with an aging society, her predicament may become more common sooner than later.   This issue will not only affect those who are not married, but also those who are widowed or divorced.   Do we have any solutions that are being drawn up?

 

     I urge the Government to beef up the Medisave account and liberalise its use for purchase of private and national

Column: 796

catastrophic illness insurance.   By this, I mean the major illnesses such as heart attack and cancer. I understand from the Health Facts Singapore 2003 that the principal causes of death in over 50% of cases are cancer and heart attack.   In many cases, the sums in an elderly person's Medisave account are not sufficient to meet his long-term medical needs.  Often, he will have to dip into his children's Medisave accounts as well. But this merely delays the problem from the current generation to the next.   What happens when the child grows old?   The better solution is the pooling of risks via catastrophic illness insurance.   I support the concept of co-funding, but I should emphasise that it should not be restricted to the coverage of hospitalisation and medical costs alone.   It should also cover the loss of income, which is especially important if the person is the sole breadwinner.  

 

     It is also clear that the CPF is insufficient to meet the needs of the aging population.  Very few people are disciplined savers who can put money away over time.  Some form of compulsory arrangements can be encouraged, whether in the form of portable pension schemes or company sponsored pension schemes.  Encouraging employers to set up pension schemes would need some pushing from the Government itself.  It would be able to stimulate a demand for quality fund management capabilities.

     Dr Chong Weng Chiew (Tanjong Pagar): (In Mandarin):  Mr Speaker, Sir, the economic prospect of Singapore this year has improved.  We are all hoping that the economic recovery this time around could be sustained successfully.  I firmly believe that with the concerted efforts between the people and the Government, we should be able to overcome the obstacles before us. 

 

     The financial policies and the Budget announced by the Deputy Prime Minister are prudent and have far-reaching implications.  This Budget is pro-business and it has also focused on helping the lower income families, eg, topping up of Medisave account for the senior citizens and more allocations for Medifund.  I support this Budget. 

 

     However, our Singapore people should learn to be more self-reliant and be less dependent on the Government.  In fact,

Column: 797

many Singaporeans are making efforts to improve themselves.  They understand that ultimately, they will have to improve their skills so that they can get a good job and not wait for the Government's allowances to help them.  I hope that the Government will set up more incentive schemes to encourage our people to upgrade themselves. 

 

     As our market is limited, the entrepreneurs have to venture overseas.  Only then can the companies have the opportunity to grow. Being unfamiliar with the new territories, the SMEs have to face a lot of obstacles.  Our Government should continue to help them.  Today, in the international market, the competition is very intense.  The various governments, including the USA and Europe, are actively helping their local businesses to win over overseas markets and contracts.  If our Government does not step up our efforts to support our local enterprises with more active and realistic actions, our engine of growth would have lost its momentum.

Column: 798

     The Government agencies should also conduct seminars to encourage Singapore business to work closely together and to avoid treating one another as  competitors.  It is said that at home, you depend on your parents, but outside you have to depend on friends.  If we cannot help ourselves, then who is going to help us?

 

     Going overseas for our business, of course, will bring some pressure to our families.  I think the Government should help to alleviate this burden.  For example, we can build more Singapore international schools or also give some grants for our businessmen to defray some school fees for their children. Without their support, the people in the SMEs would not be able to maintain their very heavy cost of living in other countries, and many of them will sacrifice the opportunity to venture overseas.

 

     On the other hand, our local entrepreneurs should also improve the attitude in their work and service, and also their desire to upgrade themselves.  Compared to Hong Kong, I think we lack flexibility and we do not have the urgent desire to succeed.  The Hong Kong people of five years ago were entirely different from what they are today.  Five years ago, the Hong Kong people may be arrogant and their standard of Mandarin was not very good.  When we spoke Mandarin to them, they could only understand half of what we said.  But, today, their service attitude is much improved, and they can speak Mandarin very eloquently.

 

     Let me now talk about our future generation and our education system.  Let me share one story with you.  A duck was showing off to the fish in the pond.  He said, "I am the most talented among all the creatures.  I can run, I can swim, I can fly.  Don't you think I am very talented?"  The fish smilingly replied, "Yes, you can run, you can swim, you can fly.  You have this multi-talent which other

Column: 799

animals do not have.  But just think about it.  When you run, you cannot run fast; and you cannot even catch up with the dogs and the cats.  Talking about swimming, you cannot swim as far as I do.  As for flying, you are the slowest and the lowest-flying among all the animals that fly. Do you still say you are the most talented?"

 

     From this story, we can see that specialty has a lot to do with excellent performance.  In our society, we have cultivated many multi-talented people, but we should also cultivate some specialists.  In order to face the challenges ahead of us, we have to restructure our education system.  That is why I hope that the Ministry of Education will give our children more room to develop their talents and skills.  I have no quarrel with the setting of basic grade requirement for the core subjects and I also support the bilingualism policy.  But, as we all know, children learn at different paces.  Therefore, I urge the Ministry of Education to change the streaming system so that every child would be able to decide on the pace at which he learns each subject, so as to avoid putting him into boxes marked "fast", "medium" or "slow" speed, just for administrative convenience.  As it is said, we want quality and not quantity.  So, in whatever we do, we will have to take this into consideration.

 

     Take the learning of Chinese.  For example, I come from a Chinese school.  But when I became a Member of Parliament, I discovered that my command of the Chinese language leaves much to be desired.  Therefore, I engaged a teacher to help me improve my Chinese.  Nowadays, a lot of Singaporeans have some basic knowledge of Chinese.  But when they go to China, they discover that their command of Chinese is very limited.  When they were talking business, I would say that they are no different from those who know no Chinese at all.  I have also come across some businessmen who

Column: 800

came from English schools who are now regretting that they did not spend more time learning their Chinese during their school days.

 

     Therefore, I urge our Government not to further lower our standard of Chinese. I fully agree with Prof. Koo Tsai Kee.  We should encourage more Singaporeans to have a better command of Chinese.  China's expanding market and rapid economic growth should be an impetus for the economic growth of Asia and even the whole world.  So if we do not catch up, we would have lost our opportunity of being the bridge between the Chinese and English-speaking people, and this opportunity once lost would not come back. 

 

      We have emerged from the ranks of a developing country and are attaining the status of a developed country.  Our education policy and our teaching of Chinese language should also be improved to meet the changes and market demand of the international economy.

     Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong (Non-Constituency Member): Thank you, Mr Speaker, Sir, for allowing me to participate in this debate.  After studying DPM's Budget Statement, I would like to take this opportunity to comment on some of the points addressed in the Minister's speech before moving on to deal with the procreation concerns and how we can help (in our own small way) to build a future of hope and opportunity for Singaporeans and our children.

 

     First, the Skills Development Fund.  Currently, the SDF's annual expense is $120 million for 600,000 training places.  We are told that it is expected to rise by $56 million to $176 million by FY09 for an increase of 166,000 additional training places.  A simple calculation shows that it costs around $200 to train a worker currently.  However, the training cost per person is expected to go up to $337 for

Column: 801

the additional 166,000 persons.  This is an additional 68% increase.  Can the Minister explain why such a drastic jump in the expected training expense?  And will the raised salary ceiling to $1,800 add to any additional business cost?

 

     Second, the new category of "S" Pass.  Sir, I am sure that this new "S" Pass will definitely increase the supply of skilled manpower from other countries to our various industries.  With the job market still stagnant and not growing, I, together with many other Singaporean skilled workers, am concerned that the increased competition from the extra supply of skilled foreign workers, introduced from the "S" Pass, is going to depress wages and salaries further.  This will make life harder and tougher for our Singapore workers who are already struggling with CPF and wage cuts.  How then to plan for more children?

 

     Third, the importance of sound public finance.  Sir, I support the Minister's position on maintaining fiscal prudence.  A balanced budget, a trim and efficient public service make for steady growth and sound philosophy of governance.  This must be encouraged.  The Government should slowly reduce its presence in the economy, market and society.  The budget, revenue and expenditure should gradually decline in percentage terms with reference to a growing GNP figure.  This will put more money in the hands of our citizens to live a more comfortable and balanced life.

 

     Fourth, the Minister said that MOF will reduce the Ministries' budgets by a percentage equal to the Productivity Growth Rate (PGR) to encourage Ministries to improve their productivity.  Sir, I do not know how the productivity growth rate is calculated.  But I am sure that if a Ministry's budget will be cut when their productivity rises, then no

Column: 802

Ministry will want to improve on their productivity and see their budgets being cut.  I think there is a wrong assumption here.  The plan may not work.  The Finance Minister may need to warn that he will cut the Minister's and the Ministry's senior officer's salary if productivity does not increase instead.  This will put more pressure on the civil service staff to improve on their budgeting and PGR, thereby adding to a reduction in the allocated budget for the Ministry.

 

     Fifth, I am happy to hear of the Minister's plan to permanently cut the budgets of almost all Ministries by 2%.  Although I had earlier called for a 10% cut at last year's Budget debate, I am still satisfied that the call has been taken up for a 2+2% cut over two years.  This will place less burden on the Government to raise revenue from the people.  Although some MPs before me are concerned about this 2% cut on the provision of service, I am confident that it is a non-issue as the civil service is not as lean as it could be yet.  There is productivity to be gained that is not achieved yet.  If the civil service can afford to suggest six months of maternity leave, it hints that the civil service is not lean and still has fat to trim.  There may be excess head count to be considered.

 

      Sixth, a small deficit at less than 0.5% of our GDP is nothing to worry about.  Depending on how the US economy is expected to perform next year after its Presidential election, the Government should not be too intent to balance the budget by FY05.  There may be a greater need to be expansionary if the US economy falters and there is no alternative engine to stimulate growth.  The back-to-back deficits should not be a cause for concern - as revenue may turn out to be stronger than projected and past experience has shown that the fiscal position tends to err on the side of caution.  The FY04 budget may turn in a smaller deficit, or even a surplus, as

Column: 803

revenue and investment returns improve while expenditure is capped.

 

     Seventh, the divestment of non-core assets.  Sir, money was asked from the budgets in the initial years of Singapore's growth to set up Temasek Holdings, EDB and all the other statutory boards and strategic businesses.  Now that some of these businesses and companies are being divested for very handsome and profitable gains, what happens to the money?  Where is the money?  It should not stay in the books of Temasek or the statutory boards, but should rightfully go back into the Government's revenue calculation as an exceptional item.  As an example, thanks to Mr Ooi Hong Leong, the Government made a 110% return on its NatSteel holding in 15 months.  All these profits should be channelled back as investment returns to the Government's revenue stream, that is, the budget.

 

     Eighth, in the same way, budgets are being set aside in the various Ministries as grants or transfers to statutory boards and other bodies to acquire land and property from the Government.  If such grants to the statutory boards for the purchase of Government properties are classified as budget expenditure, then land and property sales revenue should similarly be classified as Government revenue.  This is only fair and proper since it is in effect a book-keeping exercise - a transfer from the Government's left hand to its right hand.  In this way, the pressure to raise taxes and revenue from the people will be greatly eased, and the Government can afford to be a lot more generous to its citizens, especially to those that do National Service, either in the Armed Forces or in reproducing for our future.

 

     Ninth, building a strong society.  Sir, what makes a strong society?  No doubt, stable families, social cohesion, racial and religious harmony, secure homes and streets make for a stable society and an attractive place to live, work and play. 

Column: 804

But it is not enough.  A strong society is where different members of the society can agree to disagree in a systematic, fair and democratic manner.  We are coming along slowly, but it is still a long way to go.  Until Singapore has established strong alternative political institutions for the people to have a genuine choice, and the genuine practice of the democratic principle, we are far from being a strong society.  In that respect, more efforts have to be made for fair play and upholding the democratic principle.

 

     Tenth, concerning the rise of university tuition fees, we are told that the proportion of each cohort entering local universities will rise from 21% to 25% by 2010.  Therefore, more will go into university and more money  is required to subsidise our children's university education. Sir, this is good news and nothing to be frightened of.  It is the aspiration of every parent for their children to get into university.  It is like participating in the race and the ultimate price is for those parents whose child has been successful in getting a place in the university.  Therefore, how can the Government break faith by asking successful parents and students to pay a higher burden of the tuition fee now?  This is sending a wrong and conflicting message to parents.  On the one hand, the Government wants us to have more children.  On the other, it is telling us that the university education fee for the unborn child is going to rise, and not telling us by how much.  This promotes uncertainty and will not encourage procreation.  The Minister talks about increasing the duration of maternity leave but is totally unmindful of the grievous effect of this announcement on procreation.

 

     Eleventh, having adequate money for retirement.  Sir, while the policies will help the working generation to plan for retirement for themselves and their families, I want to talk about another 

Column: 805

issue, that is, to encourage and allow aged parents to rent out their whole flats, even if they have not finished paying their mortgage or have lived there for less than 10 years.  This is to allow them to opt to stay with their younger married children, or allowing their children to rent out the whole flat and to stay with the parents.  The rental income will help to pay for the mortgage instalment while any excess is extra money for living and retirement planning.  This will put less stress on the family, and also help to build stronger three-generational bonds as aged parents can help to take care of the grandchildren, if any.

     Lastly, I would now like to touch on the procreation issues.  Many MPs had addressed many aspects of this issue yesterday.  I would now like to add my views.

 

     Mr Speaker, Sir, parents here want the best for their children, nothing but the best.  And if that is not attainable, they will rather not have any.  If we, as citizens, are not happy with our given lot and purpose in living, and that the prospect does not look any brighter, no amount of incentives, childcare subsidy, baby bonus or maternity leave is going to help persuade young couples to have

Column: 806

more children.  This is especially so for the educated and ambitious ones.  Only those with a non-materialistic value system, or living within a strong family community or religious network, will be more persuaded to have children and more.

 

     This has all to do with the value system of our society and the young couples.  If work and career are valued as more important, then why have children?  If holidays are deemed important than the inconveniences of having a baby around, why do they want to have children?

If the opportunity cost is high, why do they want to have children?  If the dream condominium is still a distant dream, they will totally forget about having children.  The Government and the media, as lead influences in our society, have sent us a wrong message all these years: cars, careers, condominium and cash are more important goals in life than having the last "C", ie, children.  Only when some or all the other valued items have been attained or will be attained will the idea of starting the next big project "C" get some consideration.  By then, it is too late, as most women and couples are past their fertile age. 

 

     If I may observe correctly, most Ministers and high-income earners often have more than one child, some three, four or five.  Why?  Is it not because they are happy with their life, existence and achievements?  But can we say that of the rest of society, those living in 1-room, 3-room, 4-room HDB flats, especially the young and the ambitious?  Many feel like slaves slogging from day to night, short of time, short of money.  Life is a constant struggle for many.  If so, why do they want to bring another life into this Singapore to suffer their same fate?  Their prospect does not look any brighter.

 

     If the Government wants our society to reproduce itself, it must send the right and consistent message that strong

Column: 807

families with children is as important as anything else.  The Government must show that it supports and values its citizens as individuals, and not as a digit and statistic in the production process.  If citizens are constantly made to feel as a statistic, a burden on Government finance, a stress on future budgets, then citizens do not feel valued and cared for, why then would they want to reproduce their young to suffer the same fate?

 

     The correct value system of appreciation must be shown.  The Government must not shirk its social responsibility to the citizens for fear of rising subsidies.  It is high time that the Government assumed greater responsibility for healthcare and education and stopped talking about subsidies for these essential services.  After all, is this not what the taxpayers are paying for?  Constantly planning to raise healthcare cost, education cost, transport and living costs while constantly stressing our vulnerability of losing our number one status to competition to our neighbours does not help to build confidence in Singapore's future prospect.  If young couples are not confident about the future, how can we expect them to be confident about providing the best for their children?

 

     Finally, Sir, I would like to offer some points for the Government's consideration to make living easier and to attract young couples to have children. 

 

     (1)  As some Members have suggested, have a 5-day work week so that young parents will have more time together and with their young children.

 

     (2)  Encouraging more flexible working schedule for young parents and the ability to do work from home through the use of Internet technologies.  This is more beneficial than the six months of maternity leave being considered.  As any

Column: 808

career-minded woman is concerned, there may be no job left when they return after six months. 

 

     (3)  Give new mothers and young parents six years of maid levy fee waiver, so that they can employ a personal helper to take care of the newborn, them and the house.  This is definitely better and more highly valued than having cash or baby bonus incentives. 

 

     (4)  Give outsourcing contracts to ex-staff who become self-employed and work from home, so that they can better take care of their children.  They need to be encouraged with contractual work while remaining committed to raising families and children.

 

     To conclude, Sir, this is a prudent and mildly expansionary Budget.  Overall, the Government remains prudent in its expenditure.  This is also expansionary in view of the 2% point cut in corporate tax rate.  This Budget will strengthen Singapore's current recovery path.  In particular, a lower corporate tax rate will make Singapore an even more competitive business and manufacturing centre.  I believe, Sir, with the review that was in place and this Budget that is being put before us, there is more hope for our future.

 

     Sir, with this, I support the motion.

     Mr Gan Kim Yong (Holland-Bukit Panjang): Mr Speaker, Sir, in his Budget Speech, DPM Lee outlined the Government's strategy for building a strong society.  He highlighted four areas of focus:

Column: 809

     Sir, I would like to share my views on these areas.

 

     Firstly, higher education.  Indeed, our people are our strength and our most valuable asset.  The Government has consistently adopted an education strategy that allows our people to realise their potential to the fullest.  Subsidies were granted generously to finance our education programmes from pre-school to tertiary education.  This strategy has served us well.
