     Next, building the next generation.  I would like to spend a bit more time on

Column: 811

this issue, although I am not going to propose another 28 suggestions because many speakers before me have already done so.  They have made many useful suggestions, and I am sure the Government will consider them carefully and come up with a comprehensive package by National Day. 

 

     I was a little bit concerned though that there was a proposal to give special consideration to women with higher income.  While I understand that they need to make greater sacrifices and therefore may need greater inducement, I disagree though that women who earn less or are unemployed deserve less help.  The lower income family would need as much help, if not more, to cope with the cost of raising children.  I would suggest that we should provide the same incentives, regardless of the income status of the mother. 

 

     Sir, while these financial incentives will help make it easier for couples who want to have babies, I believe it is ultimately very much an issue of the heart.  Many young people today ask, "Why should I get married?  Why should I have children?"  They are worried about the responsibility.  They are concerned about the opportunity cost, and they are reluctant to give up their lifestyle.  Maybe they are missing the most important element in all these debates.  I believe there is such a thing called love.

 

     I am not the romantic kind of guy, but I am a pretty traditional one.  I remember during my time, we never had to consider whether to get married or whether to have children.  We just fell madly in love.  We wanted to spend the rest of our lives with that special person for reasons that cannot be explained.  Then, we wanted to celebrate our love by making babies.  There is a Chinese term for children which I thought was very appropriate.  Children are called "ai qing de jie jing", which means they are products of love.  They

Column: 812

are the glory of love, they are the celebration of love.  And we want to share our love with our children.  Were we worried about the future?  Were we worried about the cost of bringing up our children?  Sure, we were.  But our love and the desire to share that love overwhelmed our concerns and we boldly took that first step forward.  Sure, there were problems and difficulties that followed.  But these challenges add colour and richness to life.  If you ask parents today, I am sure few of them would regret having babies despite all the difficulties.  And I can see Dr Tan smiling!

 

     Therefore, instead of focusing on all the difficulties and run the risk of overstating these difficulties, it is perhaps important for us to step up our efforts to promote family values among our young, especially when they are still in school, before they are caught up in the rat race of the society.  We must help them see beyond themselves and appreciate the joy and fulfilment brought about by having a family.  Without this change of heart, without this element of love, we will not be able to reverse the trend.  It is like driving a car.  We have an excellent engine, whether it is a Toyota or Lexus - like Mr Khaw Boon Wan likes to refer to - we have the best driver, the best lubricant and even a full tank of fuel, but when we turn the key, the car does not start.  The reason is that there is no spark in the spark plug.  Perhaps, we should add that spark in the car.  So, I am suggesting that we should introduce an annual campaign to promote family values.  Call it the Spark Campaign or Love Campaign.  This will help to add spark into the lives of our young people.

 

     As DPM pointed out, even if we do everything right, it is almost impossible to reach the replacement rate of 2.1.  Therefore, other than producing Singapore babies, we must also bring in permanent residents and then convince them to become citizens.  Many of my friends are

Column: 813

permanent residents.  When I asked them about their reasons for not taking up citizenship, the reasons given are quite varied.  Some of them are here purely for the employment and have no allegiance to Singapore, and there is no need to talk about citizenship.  Others have family members who are still in their home country and they could not sever the ties totally.  A number of them, however, find the process of gaining citizenship rather painful, especially the younger ones who may be liable for National Service.

 

     I would, therefore, urge the Government to review the process of conversion from PR to citizenship to see if it can be simplified.  Lower the threshold so that more will become citizens.  

 

     Other than making babies and converting PRs to citizens, we must also stem our losses through emigration.  I am pleased that the Government will be reviewing the privileges for citizens versus PRs.  Indeed, there is a need to make the distinction more substantive and meaningful.  To fuel our economic growth,

we need to attract foreign talents to work here and we have to make it easier for them to gain employment pass and permanent residence. However, we need to balance that with the need to preserve the rights of our citizens. We need to create value for Singapore citizenship. However, this value must go beyond dollars and cents.  To be impacting, it must go beyond their pockets and reach their hearts. 

 

     Let me share with you an experience which I had with a joint venture company in China.  Before we could acquire control, employees of the company were paid fixed wages pegged to the local market practice.  After we acquired control, we introduced the foreign management know-how.  We started the performance-based wage system.  It all

Column: 814

sounds very well.  And, as a result, productivity improves and employees take home a much higher pay package. That is good. However, our local partner made a comment that set me thinking.  He said that in the past, the employees in the company had a strong sense of loyalty to the company.  They worked hard because they felt that the company was their home and the company took care of them.  Now, with the performance-based wage system, they work hard because of the higher pay. There is a paradigm shift among these employees. The positive factor is that they will work harder for the higher pay and this will continue to work for as long as the company remains profitable and able to pay.  The negative effect, however, is that they will readily hop to another job so long as the other job pays higher. 

 

     Therefore, to create value for citizenship, we must go beyond financial values. We must create emotional values too. This too is an affair of the heart.  I hope to talk more on this during the Committee of Supply debate. 

 

     Lastly, in ensuring adequate finances for retirement, the Government has introduced changes to the terms of CPF withdrawal to ensure adequate finances for retirement.  However, many Singaporeans are not poor per se but their wealth is tied up in assets, mainly in the real estate.  They are truly in a cashless situation.  I believe the key is to find the way to unlock these assets to free up cash.  I would like to propose to the Government to consider offering shorter lease flats or rental flats to the retirees so that they could realise some of their cash for their retirement needs. 

 

     Private pension scheme is another way to ease the retirement burden and this could be considered further.

 

     To conclude, Sir, we are at the beginning of the economic recovery cycle.

Column: 815

We need to allow our economy to deepen its roots so that it can grow in a healthy and sustainable manner.  The Budget aims to do that. At the same time, we must work towards building a strong society to ensure our survival as a nation, not just as an economy.

 

    We, as a family, must make sure that the strongest members among us will continue to thrive and help bring the rest along.  We must also make sure that the weakest among us are not left behind, but are given a helping hand.  This spirit of kinship, of interdependence and of mutual help is what made us successful so far and that same spirit will continue to be crucial to our success in the future.

     Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan (Hong Kah): Mr Speaker, Sir, to my mind, the most striking motif of Budget 2004 is the manner in which it lays out the critical social issues that loom in the not-too-distant horizon. Hence, I would venture to call it the nation-building budget.   But the Budget is also an acknowledgement that the Government has no magic wand to wave. At the end of the day, there are many trade-offs that have to be made. 

 

     Let me, first, deal with two of the more mundane but nonetheless important short-term aspects of the Statement.  Then, like those before me, and I am sure, those after me, I would like to say my piece on the subject on everyone's lips - making babies.

 

     As a woman MP, I feel compelled to lend my voice to this great Singapore baby debate, knowing full well that I am really going to sound like a broken record, if only to impress upon the Government to give weight to our - that is women's - perspectives on this issue. 

 

     My first point relates to the Government expenditure trimming.  Is this prudent practice or practising prudence?  Increasingly, the economy drive the

Column: 816

Government started some years back seems to be shifting into higher gear.  Government expenditure for almost all Ministries will be trimmed by 2% for Year of Assessment 2004 and further next year, if appropriate, to instill financial discipline.  It is interesting that this is being implemented at a time when there is widespread belief that the global and domestic economies are recovering. 

 

     That is a clear recognition that public sector profligacy is a temptation that needs great effort to resist.  I think of the gargantuan budget deficits which USA is now grappling with to finance their Iraq war effort, battle terrorism and boost consumption by cutting taxes, and I shudder to think of the long-term consequences that this may have on the mighty US economy and the rest of the world.  Unlike many countries, Singapore has generally acted prudently - some would say, too prudently - in its public finances. 

 

     However, I would urge the Ministries to ensure that the standard of service delivery to the public will not be affected by such cuts.  More importantly, in their drive to protect their own bottomlines, Ministries and statutory boards should not resort to raising fees, because this will place a heavier burden on individuals and private sector businesses.  Nor should they compensate by reducing best sourcing projects to the private sector. 

 

     Indeed, I am quite confident that the outsourcing of non-strategic projects to the private sector will yield cost savings and help towards achieving the 2% expenditure cuts.  Therefore, while the Government should be practising prudence in its financial affairs, it should not allow their practice to be too prudent.

   

     My next point relates to the middle-income squeeze.  Individuals are generally disappointed that there was no cut in the personal income tax rates or any other

Column: 817

income tax reliefs, as well as no announcements of any further rebates for utilities and HDB service and conservancy charges.  Many, though not expecting much, were expecting at least some form of tax incentives or rebates as the economy was just beginning to recover. 

 

     Moreover, the impact of this recovery has been quite localised in some industries, for example, some sectors in manufacturing, and has largely not filtered through to the economy as a whole. Workers' pay cuts have also generally not been restored and this is painful for many families. Analysts and businessmen alike believed a cut in the personal income tax rates could help stimulate domestic consumption demand and put the recovering, but perhaps still somewhat fragile economy, on an even firmer footing. 

 

     On top of this lack of "goodies" for individuals, the advance notice that university fees are set to go up, the introduction of means testing for healthcare subsidies, as well as the recent announcements of the deadline for the implementation of a flexible wage system, have brought on concerns, especially for the lower-middle and middle income groups who may be at the margins of disposable income.  For this group of people, there may be the feeling of a middle income squeeze. Some assurance is needed here that the Government will take these concerns into account when the policies on means testing and university fee revisions are deliberated and implemented.

 

     There is also some fear that the new "S" employment passes for middle-level skilled foreign labour with a minimum salary of $1,800 would compete unfairly against our local labour and nudge them out of some jobs.  The MOM and WDA must assure workers that the "S" pass

Column: 818

holders are only for industries where there is a shortage of relevant skilled workers. They should keep up efforts to help our workers, particularly the older ones, find jobs and remain employable.

 

     My next point on building the next generation.  This year's Budget acknowledges that our twin problems of a declining birth rate and an aging population could deplete our most valuable resource and thereby threaten our economic survival. We have neither land nor natural resources to speak of. What we do have is our people.  Hence, we need to focus on what DPM Lee calls "building the next generation". 

 

     I am particularly pleased that DPM Lee did not simply entitle this part of the Budget "making babies", because, in truth, the issue is not merely about having enough people to fill the slots in our production lines, or meet the Ministry of Manpower's projections on the number of PhDs we need to achieve our goals for growing the biotech sector. These, we can, to some extent, import. Instead, we need to produce many crops of young Singaporeans who are able and willing to take up arms to defend our country, to feel a bond for this place we call home.  In a nutshell, we need to build future generations of Singaporeans, born and bred here.

 

     The enormous amount of sometimes conflicting opinions and proposals that have been received goes to show that there is no quick fix nor a one-size-fits-all solution.  This vexing issue has challenged our finest minds ever since the problem was first highlighted by the then PM, SM Lee, more than 20 years ago in 1983.  Despite various measures introduced in 1987 and 2000 to arrest the birth decline, our 2003 TFR at 1.26 is even lower than the 1.6 TFR of 1983. 

 

     Yet, an MCDS' survey on the social attitudes of Singaporeans in 2001

Column: 819

indicates that the vast majority, ie, 84% of Singaporeans, agreed that it is better to get married than to remain single, and 89% agreed that married couples should have children.

 

     Common reasons cited by Singaporeans for this baby strike range from more women choosing to remain single, opportunity cost of a career versus motherhood, emergence of the 24/7 work culture, forcing employees to work even longer hours and therefore have little time or energy for bedroom exploits, job insecurity due to erosion of the concept of lifelong employment, lack of infant-care facilities, and many people's favourite bugbear, the stressful education system.

 

     Like numerous other working mothers in Singapore, I have also experienced many of these concerns.  I struggled with the decision of starting a family after I got married and deferred motherhood for six years as I had wanted to focus on my career first.  I feared that I could not cope with both having children and a career and I also wanted to further my studies.  Nonetheless, I had my first child at 31, after seeing how proud my friends were of their children and the family, love and bonding they shared.  My husband and I have never looked back on that decision since.  Now we have three children.  We could have more if  I had started earlier. 

 

     Raising three children and having a career have not been easy.  But I have been very fortunate because my husband has always shared the responsibilities of child-rearing with me and my parents are able to help me look after the children.  I know that many other working couples may not be able to rely on their parents and may face a host of problems arranging for suitable childcare. 

 

     Therefore, as is widely acknowledged, a holistic approach is needed.  We need the fiscal incentives to prod couples to have more children, and we also need the

Column: 820

physical and social infrastructure to facilitate child-minding.  But deeper than that, we need a change of mindset that puts the family - in the fullest sense of the word, and not merely referring to husband, wife and children - at its rightful place in the social psyche of our nation.

 

     This third aspect of the "baby blues" problem is what I wish to deal with and that relates to changing minds and creating life. 

 

     Let me talk about the 3Rs - re-distributing gender roles, re-balancing worklife and re-assuring the singles.

 

     First, redistributing gender roles.

The issue of procreation is linked to the larger issue of gender roles facing women and how Singapore society perceives them.  Due to societal and cultural norms still held by many Singaporeans, signals from the Government which speak of a patriarchal and male-dominated society and our own drive for self-actualisation as a result of better education, Singaporean women are torn between demands of work and their duties as wife, mother and daughter. 

 

     Sometimes, subtle or not-so-subtle discrimination which women face at the workplace adds further stress to us and, in fact, helps to compel women into an either/or situation - either a career, in which case, marriage, child-bearing and child-rearing can wait, and all the while the biological clock is ticking away, or extended motherhood, and the Singapore workforce is thereby impoverished by the loss of women who choose, even if temporarily, to leave their jobs to fulfil their other calling. 

 

     As women become increasingly more well-educated and more join the workforce, there will be more women earning more salaries than their spouses.  Hence, the notion of a patriarchy is

Column: 821

becoming more and more irrelevant.  Instead, the notion should be one of shared responsibilities between the husband and wife in all aspects of family life, including child-rearing, which should not fall squarely on the wife, just as the joys of parenthood are not exclusive to the mother.  

 

     It is, therefore, timely that the Government should look into harmonising policies on medical benefits for women in the civil service and citizenship rights of children born to a Singaporean mother but non-Singaporean father.  The justifications for these policies have basically been that we are an essentially Eastern Confucianist and patriarchal society where the husband is recognised as head of the household.  These policies should be harmonised so as to signal the equality or parity of treatment of both sexes and the Government's support for the family.  Moreover, as we seek to increase our birth rates, should we therefore not send signals to show that we welcome the foreign-born child of the Singaporean women with foreign husbands just as we do if it is the father who is Singaporean. 

 

     To further reinforce the message of shared responsibilities of men and women in parenthood and offset the concerns of discrimination of women due to extended maternity leave, fathers could be given longer paternity leave, up from the current three days to, say, at least 7-10 days.  Even Japan, a traditionally patriarchal country, has funds set aside by the Government to encourage fathers to go on leave as it recognises that the willingness of men to help care for the child and do household chores will affect their wives' desire to have children. 

 

     One concern some of my male parliamentarians have shared with me as to why longer paternity leave or some other permutations will meet with

Column: 822

resistance from the Committee on Procreation, is that this will add to the current leave employers will have to give to our NS men for reservist training and thus again add to employers' cost.  My rejoinder will be that if making children is now considered as crucial as fighting for the country, surely one solution could be to look at offsetting at least part of the extra days of paternity leave from the reservist training period.  Additionally, tax incentives, such as child relief and maid levy, should not only be made more attractive but also allowed to be taken by either the husband or wife so that it is not only working mothers that can benefit.

 

     Let me share that it takes much more courage and sacrifice for the women to decide not to work in order to look after their children and this should again be applauded and not penalised.  In sum, parenthood and not motherhood should be promoted so that women would truly feel that there is gender parity and need not have to vacillate between career or child-rearing.  They can opt for both if they desire.

 

     Secondly, re-balancing work life.  One of the victims the stresses of a fast-paced and competitive environment have claimed is the low fertility of Singapore couples.  Even those who wish to conceive may find either time has passed them by because they have focused so much attention on growing their career just to keep up with their peers, or that they face stress-related biological difficulties. 

 

     Sir, I am greatly tempted to argue for a slower pace of life so that we can stop and smell the roses.  But, I also know that there is a thin line between the loss of our competitive drive and the desire to have a more flexible life-style choice, because nobody owes us a living.  Couples need to re-balance work and family life and employers can help to provide a more family-friendly work environment by being

Column: 823

flexible in their HR practices.  Best practices would include things like alternative work schedules, flexi-time, part-time job, job sharing and such.  Such flexi-work arrangements are not just beneficial to employees with young children, but also those with elderly to care for.  With an increasingly ageing population, more and more we are having a workforce that is buckling under the strain of caring for both the young and the old. 

 

     Companies in the West which implemented family-friendly work practices have found that instead of hindering productivity, there has been lower staff turnover, reduced absenteeism, more motivated employees and enhanced performance.  This has in turn enabled the company to attract a quality workforce and boosted profits.  HP in the US reported that encouraging employees to work flexible hours has led to a turnover rate which is lower than the industry average, whilst at a Xerox customer operations site, there was reduced absenteeism when flexi-time was implemented. 

 

     The Straits Times dated 5th March 2004 reported that although the civil service has a number of family-friendly work practices in place, in the last five years, just 900 or 1.5% of the 60,000 civil servants have some kind of flexi-work arrangements.  There may be some resistance from immediate supervisors unable to see the long-term benefits of a family-friendly approach because of short-term cost and disruptions.  If the civil service were to become a model family-friendly employer to set the example and lead other organisations, then all civil servants who are in charge of staff must be convinced that the organisation will benefit from such arrangements.  Private sector firms too need to be convinced of the merits of allowing flexi-work arrangements as these are hardly found in most private sector firms now, except the

Column: 824

MNCs.  The Manpower Ministry, together with WDA and NTUC, could develop best practices, go on a publicity blitz and highlight case studies of how overseas and local organisations can successfully implement such work arrangements without suffering from negative impact.  They could form a tripartite task force to work with companies seeking to develop such practices, similar to what was done for the flexi-wage system. 

 

     I would also like to ask the Government to seriously reconsider adopting the 5-day work week as one of its family-friendly practices, as many of my parliamentary colleagues before me have spoken on.  When this was first proposed by the Remaking Singapore Committee to allow Singaporeans more time to spend with their families, build stronger bonds and improve their quality of life, it was opposed rather robustly on grounds that it would reduce our productivity and competitiveness which we can ill-afford.  However, having a 5-day work week does not necessarily reduce productivity.  Firstly, many manufacturing companies, as well as numerous other private sector companies, are already on a 5-day work week.  My company, for instance, was on the alternate Saturday-off system, as we felt that clients may want to meet us on Saturdays.  Three years ago, we implemented the 5-day work week as we felt that there was not much achieved staying open on Saturdays.  Firstly, there was much confusion caused as some staff swapped their Saturdays for various reasons.  Secondly, productivity was low on Saturdays as inevitably many exhibited the "weekend is here, time to go slow" syndrome.

 

     Since we started on a 5-day work week, we have not suffered from any loss of productivity of business and, of course, staff are much happier.  Additionally, it must be noted that a 5-day work week does not mean that an organisation

Column: 825

cannot remain open on Saturdays.  For Government and other organisations that need to do so, a staggered 5-day work week could be implemented.  I understand, for instance, that IRAS is already on a 5/5/6 schedule.  With some effort and a little imagination, the 5-day work week can be instituted without loss of quality of service or productivity.  With the 5-day work week and with other flexi-work arrangements, family members could spend more time with each other and perhaps our divorce rates, which have been increasing, could be reduced. 

 

     Finally, my third point, re-assuring the singles.  In all the discourse about procreation and motherhood, we must not unwittingly discriminate against the singles.  There is a need to assure our singles that they are an equally important part of our society and equally valued.  Single women aged 15 years and above, for instance, form a sizeable portion of our workforce, 38%, or about 350,000 as at June 2003, of all employed women in Singapore.  The absolute number is even higher than the number of employed single males aged 15 years and above, which is about 320,000.  Assurances must be given that their concerns, such as some tax relief for looking after their aged parents, like in the form of foreign maid relief or family leave instead of maternity or paternity leave to look after the aged sick, could be considered.  Singles, particularly women who are single by default and not by choice because they hitherto had been unable to find a suitable life partner, need help.  At the individual level, the dilemma facing them as well as working women is not very different:  how to balance work with their personal or social life? 

 

     At the national level, how to balance the need for manpower, or more correctly woman power, in the workforce with our drive to raise the fertility rates?  I would

Column: 826

urge the SDU to continue redoubling its effort, even if the success rate is not very high.  Each successful match gives the potential of at least one more baby.  Perhaps SDU could start programmes even at the tertiary institutions, say, in conjunction with orientation and later perhaps a preparatory course for final year students on grooming, communication, social and interview skills to prepare them for their work and social life and allow them more opportunities to meet.

 

     I also urge the Government to relook at rules to permit adoption of children and guardianship by single women.  Perhaps there is concern that such children growing up in an incomplete family environment will grow up dysfunctional.  But I believe the risk is worth taking in order to confer the joys of motherhood and satisfy the maternal instincts of single women who, for biological or other reasons, are unlikely to be able to find a mate and procreate.  Indeed, the decision to have children is ultimately not about the incentives but rather the whole experience of parenthood.  Mating and procreation are part of our DNA, ensuring the survival of a species.  But beyond that, as any parent, myself included, can attest to, there is unspeakable joy in raising children.  Caring for a baby, stroking his hair, watching him learn to walk, utter the first syllables, return from school with excitement at what the teacher has taught, watching him play with new friends, win a competition, eventually going through university, graduating, marrying and having his own children, this is, as one recent property advertisement would say,  "priceless". 

 

     As can be seen from the multitude of sometimes divergent measures that have already been proposed both in and outside of this House, there can be no one perfect solution as there will always be trade-offs.  There will be some pain to be borne by employers, employees themselves, and the state.  To me, the path to more babies

Column: 827

must begin with the mindset change from all three parties in terms of their attitude towards women in the workforce, responsibilities of child-rearing and the perceived role of women in society.  But above all else, Sir, I would like to stress that, even as the Committee on Procreation evaluates the multitudes of possible measures, I urge them to please listen to the women.

 

     With this, I support the Budget.

     Dr Mohamad Maliki Bin Osman (Sembawang): Mr Speaker, Sir, thank you for giving me the opportunity to join in the debate.

 

     I was away when the Budget Statement was delivered in Parliament a week ago.  The reaction I received upon my return, when I asked about the Budget was, "What budget?"  A journalist related that after DPM Lee finished his statement, she and her colleagues looked around at each other and asked, "That's it?"  To the man-in-the-street, Sir, the message of the Budget is still as unclear as last year's.  To them, the key word is:  It is a pro-business Budget.  Indeed, that was how it was reported in the media the next day.  The only thing that they got out of the Budget is the hope that businesses would do well with this pro-business budget and thus their jobs would be secure, more jobs will come their way,

with the promise of more Foreign Direct Investments (FDIs).

 

     In his Budget speech, DPM Lee also mentioned that Singapore remains competitive as a manufacturing location, especially for high-tech, high value-added activities.  According to DPM Lee, last year, we attracted about US$7.6 billion in Foreign Direct Investments.  Sir, to the man-in-the-street, it can mean two things:  (1)  Wow!  That's a lot of money!  But what's in it for me?  More job optiions?  Lower risk of retrenchment?  No more pay cut?  And (2) a question is raised:  is this US$7.6 billion good?  What was the

Column: 828

target set and was this figure below or above the target?  Are we expecting better FDIs with the current fiscal policy and budget provisions?

 

     Sir, as far as the man-in-the-street is concerned, this Budget is only for and about businesses, and the larger businesses at that, as pointed out by some of my colleagues in this House.  So, will the Budget that is meant to benefit the businesses actually have the desired multiplier effect of bringing in the investment dollar and the jobs?

 

     The first point I want to make is the Budget and its promise I: More investment dollar?  Sir, we have heard much about how the new economies are giving us a run for our money in terms of their competitive labour and production costs.  A report by the Asian Development Bank in 2003 titled "Key Indicators of Developing Asian and Pacific Countries" showed that our share of the FDIs coming to Asia is fast getting smaller.  Amongst the South East and East Asian countries, we used to have about 23% of the FDI pie in 1991, similar to China's.  But our share has been steadily declining to a low of 4.25% in 2000 and 7.7% of the pie in 2001.  China, on the other hand, has taken almost half of the FDI pie in 2001, due for Asia.  Sir, the above is a layman's interpretation of the figures.  I stand corrected in terms of my interpretation.

   

     But, Sir, I wonder if DPM Lee can share with us the Government's thinking behind the relationship between the Budget and our FDI position vis-a-vis the other countries in South East and East Asia.  What is our target in terms of the FDI pie that we hope to capture with the various fiscal policies in this Budget and that of the previous or subsequent few years?  Sir, we owe it to the people to give them hope and promise.  We need to tell them that although this Budget is "pro-business", it is actually "pro-Singaporeans", as Singaporeans will

Column: 829

benefit from the multiplier and systemic effects.  So, what are the promises that we can give the people with this Budget?

 

     Secondly, the Budget and its promise II:  More jobs?   Sir, we have been plagued with the problem of unemployment for the past couple of years.  Much has been done to our fiscal policy to arrest the problem.  From direct pay cuts to cuts in employer's CPF, Singaporeans have been biting the bullet.  Again, for this Budget, we are telling Singaporeans to be patient.  Although there is nothing outright for them in terms of tax rebates, etc, the Budget is meant to increase our competitiveness, and the end product  -  more jobs for Singaporeans.

 

     Sir, it is hard for Singapoerans to reconcile the above. To many Singaporeans, it is a simple equation  -  better things equal more jobs, fewer retrenchments, better take-home pay, lesser problems with monthly bill payments.  But they are not seeing this.

 

     The messages are rather confusing.  They hear the Acting Minister for Manpower telling the press that we have a yearly shortage of 350,000 workers till 2009.  Yet, they also hear of the over 95,000 unemployed Singaporeans with an unemployment rate of 5.4% as at September 2003.  Despite this, they are hearing that more foreigners are needed to fill the jobs that Singaporeans are not sufficiently skilled in.  Sir, some may conclude:  "Yes, the jobs may be created from the Budget policies, but it is not for me.  It is for the engineer, Mr Chong, from China perhaps, the IT professional, Mr Logan, from India, or the nurse, Ms Imelda, from the Philippines."  Is that so?

 

     Are the 95,000 unemployed Singaporeans the so-called structurally unemployed whose skills set is so bad that they cannot fit into any of these

Column: 830

350,000 jobs that the Acting Minister for Manpower talks about?  Among the 95,000 unemployed, we have 15,500 who are degree holders, while another 8,500 who are diploma holders.

 

     Sir, another related question will be:  why are we bringing jobs that Singaporeans are not skilled for?  Have we no choice?  What is the hope that we are giving Singaporeans with this Budget?  Can they look forward to something more observable?

 

     Thirdly, outsourcing:  the threat to white collar workers.  Sir, DPM Lee also touched on MOF's decision to introduce "best sourcing" for new services policy.  This also relates to the concept of "outsourcing" services to those who can provide the services at the lowest cost.  If I recall correctly to a question by Dr Amy Khor on the impact of outsourcing on the Singapore economy and jobs, the Minister for Trade and Industry replied that we are targeting higher value-added jobs in the global outsourcing market.  I suppose this suggests that we have the skilled manpower for these higher value-added jobs performed by trained white collar workers that will be outsourced to Singapore.  But, Sir, I think the global trend is showing that the real theat for Singapore not only comes from competition for the lower-end jobs but also from the high-end jobs, ie, white collar jobs.  Recent trends and studies in the US show that white collar jobs are increasingly coming under the threat of workers in India and China.  If the workers in the US are facing the threat, we cannot assume that we are immune to this threat.

 

     For jobs to stay in Singapore, we need workers, white collar and blue collar alike, who are either cheaper or much better, which gives the same end result, ie, higher productivity.  Sir, a Business Week report dated 3rd February 2003 noted that China produces 322,000 graduates

Column: 831

and 41,000 post-graduates, and India produces 251,000 graduates and 63,000 post-graduates in just 1999  -  that is more than a quarter of the total Singapore workforce.  We are also hearing that all these graduates and postgraduates are asking for salaries that no Singaporean counterpart will work for.

 

     Sir, at the end of the day, the issue is no longer just telling the aunties and uncles in the factories that their jobs are threatened.  The larger issue is that everyone's job is threatened  -  the investment banker, the IT engineer, etc.  How is the Budget addressing these issues?  What can Singaporean white collar workers do to face up to the competition?  What is in the Budget that addresses this growing threat?

 

     Next, keeping the job, paying the mortgages and having children, a topic that has been much discussed in the House in the past two days.  Another much anticipated announcement that never came during the Budget Statement was:  what is in it for Singaporeans to have more children?  A week after the delivery of the Budget Statement, I did my regular block visit in my constituency.  Many of those whom I met were young couples either without children or having only one child.  Their response to my question on when they will have their first or next child was interestingly similar  -  wait till August and see what the Government has to offer.  Sir, yes, they may say it in jest or they may actually mean it.  Whatever it is, it is quite sad that young Singaporeans will actually wait for what the Government will offer before thinking about having one or two kids. But, Sir, from the economic situation confronting them, we cannot really blame them.

    

     While previously white collar workers can feel comfortable about their jobs and incomes, today, they face serious threats from counterparts in other countries. 

Column: 832

Worse, these competitors are coming here through the "S" passes.  We are now thinking of further financial incentives to attract women to have more children, ie, to help couples defray the cost of having children.  I do not doubt that financial incentives will be attractive to these couples, but I would argue that there are more fundamental issues that will have to be addressed first.

 

     Next, beyond the baby dollar.  Sir, it is so interesting to note that whenever the discussion on declining fertility rate arises, the bulk of the related issues raised were about women, and often-times by women  -  women in the labour force, flexi hours for women, extended maternity leave, work-life balance.  Career women have always been asked:  how do you strike the balance?  Who looks after and manages the children and household for you?  It is as though the issue of declining fertility rate is solely a women's issue.  Perhaps that is why we have not been able to reverse the trend  - our minds have not been sufficiently reversed or, should I say, liberated.  We must stop thinking that declining fertility rate is a women's issue  -  it is as much a men's issue!  And I am not just talking about making babies!  It is only up till recently that we spoke of paternity leave and child sick leave for men.

 

     Sir, indeed, men must not think that pregnancy is a women's issue alone.  A significant turning point in my life was when my wife and I met an American several years ago when we were living in the US.  My wife was a couple of months pregnant at that time with our first baby.  The American man asked how pregnant was my wife.  She answered "five months", and his response was, "Oh, we are six months pregnant!"  It took my wife and I a couple of minutes to figure out what he meant.

 

     Sir, he owned the pregnancy and I suppose he felt psychologically pregnant. 

Column: 833

His wife was very lucky.  In the US, it is a norm for husbands to accompany wives to pre-natal check-ups.  When I returned to Singapore, I do not see the same norm amongst Singaporean men.  Perhaps it is slowly changing, but I am sure the pace can be boosted.

 

     Sir, we must make sure that men play a more significant role in the equation.  The marriage statistics recently show that our graduate women and our primary and lower educated men are remaining single.  The Government is rightfully concerned about this trend.  It has direct effect on the fertility problem.

 

     Why is this happening?  One explanation is that men, in general, prefer to marry down.  Reason?  Psychological comfort, ie, prescribed as the head of the household, they probably feel that they must be one up on their spouses, in education, if not in income.  A sociological explanation to this rests on the concept of manhood and how comfortable men are with their manhood in their choice of a life partner.

 

     Sir, this is one of the fundamental issues we have to address  -  men must be comfortable with their manhood and thus treat their partners as equals.  As a Government, we must also recognise this.  Family policies must treat men and women as equals.  Only then, I think, will men recognise the critical role that they play in not only bearing but raising children.  Only then will we send the strong message to our women folk that they should and will be supported when they bear our children.

 

     When they ask:  will their career be at risk?  The answer will be no,  because we will put in place a system that will not discriminate against women when they give birth.  The risk is even higher if we go ahead with the proposed lengthened

Column: 834

maternity leave.  Will they struggle in juggling the demands of being a career woman and a mother?  The answer must be no, because their husbands will share the responsibilities of raising the children and be equally effective parents, more than just relying on foreign domestic helpers.

 

     Sir, to achieve the latter, I have argued before in this House that we can no longer expect families to operate with gender specific roles.  Roles exist in families and couples must be comfortable to complement each other in performing these roles.  The environment in the family must be one that is mutually supportive for the couple.  We can give them more financial incentives; we can make it easier for them to have child care givers.  But we cannot ensure that they can support each other unless we send a clear message that child bearing and rearing responsibility is shared.

 

     Sir, in his commentary in the Straits Times dated 27th February 2004 titled "What Singapore needs to boost birth rate", Janadas Devan argued that Southern European countries like Spain, Italy and Greece and East Asian countries like Japan have lower fertility rates compared to countries like the US, Iceland, New Zealand because the former still holds on to traditional attitudes towards women compared to the latter.  He quoted Professor Lena Sommestad, an economics historian at Sweden's Uppsala University, as saying "birth rates are particularly low in countries that support traditional patterns of marriage and breadwinning."  Singapore is currently in the same state.  If we continue to hold on to the traditional patterns of marriage and breadwinning, we will continue the downward slope of declining birth rates of Japan and the other Southern European countries. 

 

     Socialisation and parenting the future generation.  Sir, what we do today will

Column: 835

have significant effects tomorrow.  The changes in our fiscal and tax policies today are meant

for a better economic outlook tomorrow.  So too, will be the effects of what we do at home today.  It will determine the family life of tomorrow.  We must start re-examining the way we socialise our boys and girls.  Today, we raise our girls to be educated, independent thinkers, able to stand tall with their male counterparts.  We want them to be career women and succeed.  Are our boys raised to appreciate and respect these aspirations that we have for our girls?  Are they raised to treat their female siblings and friends as equals?  How can they do so if they do not see their fathers doing exactly that?  Men must begin to recognise the critical role that they play in raising their sons and daughters.  Children will observe and model the behaviours of their parents.  They will observe if dad will be around if mum is busy at work, or will mum be the only one there all the time, in sickness or in health.

 

     Sir, the issue of reversing the declining birth rate is indeed multifaceted.  Much has been said about cost.  It is sad to think about dollars and cents when it comes to having children, most Singaporeans do take that into serious consideration.  Many of the speakers before me have highlighted the serious financial constraint on young couples.  Sir, we cannot blame them.  We raise them in comfort and with high personal aspirations.  We raise them - boys and girls - with the value that they must be educated, have a good career, have a good paying job, have an apartment of their own.  But we also have to address the broader societal issues that affect marriage and family life if we are to address the problem of falling birth rates.

 

     Sir, as a society, we must be clear of our social objectives.  We must be clear about the position that women hold in society.  We cannot send mixed signals

Column: 836

where, on the one hand, we raise our girls to be educated, career minded, and yet, at the same time, they have to be a dutiful wife and mother, while the men remain as heads of households and maintain the one-up position.  It will not work.  The women's movement has been very successful in bringing forward advancement of women in many spheres.  But I fear our men are still lagging behind in catching up with their female counterparts.  Our governmental policies must reflect our political will to change the needed mindset and for a new order of gender relationships.

 

     Sir, indeed as Janadas Devan puts it, "What we need is a social ideology that not only approves of women having careers but also encourages equality both at work and at home."  Certainly, there is more that we, Singaporean men, must do to advance this social ideology.  We not only need to play our part in making babies, but also to assure our spouses that we will be there to raise these babies together, in a mutually supportive and respectful environment.

 

     Sir, to conclude, I am sure my male colleagues would be wondering what am I doing standing here fighting for the right of women.  To the women folk, I do want to share that men understand their issues too.  Yes, the voices of the 15 women in the House are loud, or we can make it even louder with men supporting these voices.  Sir, in the end, we are fighting for the rest of our children to be raised by both women and men.

     Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong (Tampines): Sir, I would like to focus on the emphasis placed in this year's Budget on solving the problem of the falling birth rate.  I am sure that many married women will cheer at the raft of measures being considered from longer maternity leave, better childcare, more affordable childcare to more generous baby bonuses. 

 

Column: 837

     I would like to make three points.  My first point is that such measures by themselves may not be enough to check the falling fertility rate if we do not make a decisive shift from our patriarchal system to a more gender-equal one.  Indeed, the OECD experience does show that such policies have a clear positive impact on fertility only if combined with changes towards more gender-equal parenting practices, as has also been pointed out by Dr Maliki.

 

     Sir, we often hear our policy makers say, sometimes with a deep sigh of regret, that the reason for our falling fertility rate is because our women are getting better educated and they are getting more active in their workforce, as if that is something that is not to be applauded.  But it is instructive to note that, in many countries in the developed world which see even higher female participation rate in the workforce and even more higher educated women, the fertility rates vary, ranging from around replacement rate to those that are seriously below this level.  Clearly, these two factors on their own - the higher education of women and their labour force participation - are not able to explain the level of diversity in fertility rates.

 

     Other societal factors are also likely to be contributing to the varying outcomes.  There is a big respectable body of research in the developed countries that suggests that falling fertility is related to the ways in which the society as a whole is organised and that family arrangements have a bearing on the issue.

 

      In his paper published in the Journal of Population Research in the year 2000, a demographer, Prof. Peter McDonald, described two broad approaches to family responsibilities - the "male breadwinner" model and the "gender equity" model - that play a significant part in a country's

Column: 838

fertility rate.  He found that, in general, developed countries characterised by the male breadwinner model, such as Italy, Spain, East Asian countries, like Singapore, will have a lower fertility rate than those characterised by the gender equity model, such as found in the Nordic countries.  The male breadwinner model has policies that support the male-dominant family structures, such as those that place greater emphasis on the role of women in caring for dependants and that make the employment of women difficult.  Social security and social insurance are also premised on the notion that the husband would be supporting the wife and the children.  On the other hand, the gender equity model is based upon the principles of equal respect for men and women, equality of resources and capabilities, and places greater emphasis on providing services, such as childcare, services for the aged and flexible working hours that allow the women to continue working after childbirth.

 

     Sir, it recognises that many women prefer to work after childbirth, not only for the money, but also to maintain skills, social contacts, personal satisfaction and to ensure longer-term security.  Research based on the longitudinal data from the US national survey of families and households, 1987 to 1988, and 1992 to 1994, supports the idea that gender role attitudes of men and women have an important impact on family formation and dissolution.  The research found that egalitarian men are accepting of working wives and sharing household tasks and egalitarian women are more likely to want children and to be more content in their relationship if they received more support from the men.

 

     It is useful to note that perhaps no country has moved further away than Sweden from the male-breadwinner model of the family towards a more gender equal one and that it has adopted family-friendly policies to a greater extent than any other

Column: 839

country.  And it is also among the most successful in checking its falling fertility rate.

 

     In Singapore, we are a bit schizophrenic.  On the one hand, the traditionalists among us cling to the idealised patriarchal family model.  They want our women to return home and to produce more babies and that should be the priority and their main role.  And the men should be the head of the household, and the household and the country will be at peace.  The corporatists among us want women to work hard, be professional and productive at the workplace because we are short of skilled labour.  We have invested in our women's education and training and we expect them to perform, to be professionals, to work shifts and to work weekends.  The company's profits and the country's GDP must come first.

 

    Sir, we cannot help but be conflicted in our own policy making and it shows.  This incoherence can be detrimental to our childbearing and marriage rates.  The present generation of young men and women do not see their future, in terms of the male breadwinner model of the family.  If women are provided with opportunities nearly equivalent to men in education and employment, but these opportunities are felt to be severely curtailed by getting married and having children, then chances are that women will either not get married or restrict the number of children that they have.

 

     The better way forward, I believe, is to provide families with better opportunities and choices both at home and at work, and let them structure their own personal relations at home.  For some women, professional status and separate earning streams are very important.  These families need ways to simplify or outsource many aspects of their home jobs.  Others will want to spend more of their time on the family and will need to have part-time careers to facilitate the

Column: 840

roles they want to play at home.  Many families will want one thing at one time and something else at another time of their life.

 

     As the Government, we should not be dictating to families how they should structure their relations at home - who is the head of the household and so on.  We should review and do away with all employment practices and policies that are biased against women or that uphold the male breadwinner model.  It is neither helpful nor necessary.  Other than the state, the workplace has also failed to adapt to this changing reality.  Workplaces mainly have the structure they had when all employees were full-time males.  They are intolerant of part-time employees, who often function without benefits and without reasonable career paths.  They are also suspicious of parents who take leave to care for their family or who ask for more flexible hours.  They see such requests as a lack of professionalism and commitment to the company.

 

    Sir, changing the work culture as well as the work practices and expectations of corporate managers are critical.  The clearest way we can send the signal is by making it a statutory right for parents of children aged under six to apply to work flexibly.  Their employers will then have a duty to consider these requests seriously.  Such a right already available in some advanced countries does not provide an automatic right to work flexibly, as there will always be circumstances when the employers are unable to accommodate the employee's desired work pattern.  But it gives the right to the employee to apply for flexible arrangement and encourages the employer to find a solution that suits them both.

 

     My second point is that we must also recognise the changing role of men.  Although men are not as actively involved in day-to-day family life as women are,

Column: 841

there has been a substantial shift in expectations about this involvement, especially among the younger generation.  Many young fathers especially tell me they wish to have more time with their children.  Increasingly, I see more fathers accompanying their children to art competition and to family carnivals over the weekends and they will tell me, "Oh, my wife is busy because she is at work."  But they have a good time, spending time with their children and taking the children out.  I know of one marketing manager who quit his job for a year to spend time with his freelance writer wife and two young children.  His wife described that one year as the happiest time for the family.  But they would have preferred an arrangement where he could have worked part-time or taken a longer paternity leave so that they could manage their finances better.  But such options are not readily open to men.

 

     The civil service should set the lead by giving up to two weeks' paternity leave.  Most men want to be more involved and saw barriers associated with the workplace, such as expectations of long and irregular working hours, inflexibility, constant traveling, as being the most critical factor in preventing them to be the kind of father they want to be.  They are also reluctant to take family-related benefits for fear of being seen to be lacking in commitment to work.

 

     Sir, there is an unhealthy belief in Singapore that you have to work unduly long hours to show commitment to the company.  This sort of thinking must be debunked, especially in this information age.  This idea that "longer hours mean better work attitude" is perpetuated by our stance against a five-day work week.  As has been pointed out by some MPs before me, whenever we appeal for this, we were always told that it would send a wrong signal to investors that we are not

Column: 842

the hard-driving and hardworking society that we are.  I hope sincerely that the Government will reconsider its thinking on this.  As many have pointed out before me, it does not mean that offices have to close on weekends or at 5.00 pm, or it does not mean that we will become less productive or less competitive as a nation. 

 

     The Americans log fewer hours per week than Singaporeans, yet they lead the globe in productivity and competitiveness.  All EU countries have legislated the five-day work week

and some of them, eg, Finland, the Netherlands, beat Singapore in the global ranking for world competitiveness.  Asia's two largest economies have already moved to a 40-hour week, with Japan changing in 1988 and China in 1997.  South Korea also moved to a 5-day week in 2001.  And they are doing all right.

 

     Finally, singles, a growing group.  One reason often cited for staying single is the lack of time for relationships and for socialising as their hours get longer and their working hours get more irregular.  Now, with the proposed maternity leave and flexible hours, the different arrangements for parents, the situation is likely to get worse for singles.  Singles will have to cover for their married counterparts when their married counterparts go for maternity or paternity leave, child sick leave and so on.  And with their married siblings focused on feeding their own growing brood, singles will also often have to take over the responsibilities of caring for their elderly parents or disabled siblings.  The work stress on singles will be higher.  Hours at work will get longer.  Chances to socialise and meet a partner will become even slimmer. 

 

     Other than the 5-day week, which would also help singles lead a more balanced life, I would urge the Government to give more generous tax rebates to singles who care for their elderly parents and disabled siblings.  This

Column: 843

group should also be allowed to claim the foreign maid levy tax relief.  This would send the signal that the Government values the role they play in supporting the family. 

 

     Even as we help families to procreate, we must bear in mind the implications on the life of singles.  Many do not choose to be single;  many do not choose not to have children.  In fact, if you talk to many single women, they would like to have children.  In fact, just last night, I had a single woman who came to my meet-the-people session.  She has adopted a child from an orphanage in China, and she has brought up the child as if it were her own.  She said she does not want to get married because she has not found a man that she wanted to marry, and rather than have a miserable marriage, she would like to be the best mother that she could be. 

 

     In Singapore, in my dialogues with various singles, they also say they want to have children.  Is it possible for them to adopt?  I am not sure what the Government's position is on this.  But, I think, if they can be good mothers and if they can provide a good childhood for these children, we should consider making it easier for single women to adopt children and not put them through so many hoops and make them feel a bit weird for becoming mothers to adopted children. 

 

     At the same time, I would urge the Government to also not overdo the campaign to send the message that everybody should get married and have more children.  If we keep harping on this, the message to singles is that: "You are a failure, no matter what other achievements you might have accomplished in your personal or professional life, and that you are a misfit."  If we make Singapore so unwelcoming to singles that they feel out of place, and the workplace so stressful that they burn out, the mobile professionals will just take off to cities in

Column: 844

the world which allow them to live as they want to, and then we will have another problem on our hands - that of a brain drain. 

 

     Sir, in conclusion, the way we are approaching the procreation problem today is rather like a gardener looking into his toolkit.  There is this spade of financial incentives that worked well in this country, there is this changkul of childcare facilities that worked well in this other country, and so on, and then we use them to plant an apple tree in this hot and humid climate.  My point is that it is not so much the individual tools that matter or what is in the toolkit that matters, but the climate, the nature of society as a whole.  Clearly, we have to fix our climate to make it more gender-equal and more family-friendly, if we want to see more women getting married and having more babies.  Dr Amy Khor ended her speech by saying, please listen to women.  I would like to add: please listen to women as equals.

he refused to kneel before the King.  The King of Hades reprimanded him, saying, 'Although you had not accepted bribes and were not corrupt, you had accomplished nothing as an official of the imperial court.  Everything you did, you merely went by the book.  You only wanted to protect yourself and be non-committal in everything.  You did not speak out boldly to uphold justice, neither did you show solicitude for the sufferings of the people.  As an official, you were indifferent and incompetent.  Therefore, you are also guilty.'      I will just give you an example.  If I have to do a trial that starts on Monday morning, the trial preparation starts three weeks before that.  I have to read the bundles, some of which go into thousands of pages, I have to do the opening statement, I have to go through the authorities, I have to prepare for my cross-examinations - that takes time.  It may mean that I cannot come back in time to do dinner, it may mean that I may not be there on the weekends.  So I would need to feel that the husband is there taking care of part of that role, which basically means that what you are looking at is societal change.  Because our society still does have the mindset that it is more of the woman's role rather than the man's.  This is changing.  It is true.  But when you are making a policy, all I suggest is

Column: 889

that that policy needs to take into account this mindset change because if you do not take that into account, then you are only addressing symptoms and not necessarily the cause.

 

     The third perspective is the perspective of an employer.  A lot of the ground reaction to the proposals for six months' maternity leave has been that employers are not in favour of this and that there is a possibility they will not employ women as a result.  The point is that if you do want to address this baby problem and, at the same time, take into account the woman's desire to work, that is going to have to change.  It is either one or the other. It is very difficult to have it both ways.  You cannot retain the same employment mindset and, at the same time, expect things to work out.  The Government's reaction may well be that this is something for employers to decide.  There is not that much that one can do about it.  But my response to that would be that has never stopped the Government before if it has considered it really important.

 

     Take the issue of flexi-wage.  The Government considers that important because it is necessary for our economic survival.  If you want to have more babies and, at the same time, allow the women to continue to work, then this is something that you will have to address in the same way that you were prepared to address the flexi-wage issue.  So, it really boils down to two main points on what I have been saying, which is that whatever policy you formulate, there are two main cornerstones that you are going to have to change: there has to be a change in societal mindset as the role the man has to play and there has to be a change in the employer's mindset.

 

     I know this from personal experience because my secretary who has worked for

Column: 890

me for many years, in fact she has been with me since 1998, when she had her first baby, she said to me:  "Ms Rajah, I cannot stay late and work anymore because I am having my baby.  Do you mind if I go home at 5.30 pm sharp?"  At that time we finished at 5.30 pm but she very often stayed till about 6.30 pm, sometimes 7.00 pm, to help me clear the work.  I said, "Yes, it is not a problem."  Then her second child came along and it became more difficult for her and she asked me whether she could go on no-pay leave.  It was a bit of a struggle, but I understood that family was important and it was important to her, and I find family important as well, and also I understood her desire to work because she wanted to come back at the end of six months.  She did not want to feel that she would have lost her job or lost her position.  So I said, "Yes, by all means, go ahead and take your no-pay leave."  I struggled in those six months, not the most enjoyable months of my life, but it was worth it because she came back at the end of it and she continues to work with me to this day.  So, it is not that employers cannot do it.  They can do it.  It is just a question of how determined you are to do it. 

 

     In terms of mindset, let me just say this.  Our Government has never shirked from changing mindset if it has to.  Look at what we did in 2001.  We told Singaporeans, the world has changed, gobalisation is now something that will not go away.  The workforce is changing.  We must change or risk becoming irrelevant.  We were prepared to say that for entrepreneurialship and to change the mindset as far as the economy was concerned.  Well, the women have changed.  There is no going back.  If you want to have more children then you would have to make this mindset change or you face the risk of becoming extinct.

 

     And with that, Mdm Deputy Speaker, I conclude my speech and would like to support the Budget.
